text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’ve got a, we’ve got to try to kill the cells another way. Patient: Sneak up on it another way. Uh. Doctor: Pretty much. Speaking of which, Dr. C___ says hi. Patient: Oh. Doctor: I just had a meeting with him last week. Patient: Oh tell him I said hello next time you see him. Doctor: Yep. I was uh, I was talking to him. I said you got any idea? He goes, yeah, no, just do the chemo too. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Anyways. So I picked his brain.

text: Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And to be together. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So everything we’ve done so far is to try to keep the ball away from the glove. (Beeping) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The cancer sometimes will evolve a form of the glove that doesn’t need a ball. It, it still works.

text: Healthcare Professional: As of right now, yes. Doctor: Ok, I gotta do something about that. Doctor: So I can't believe so many people are willing to come in the week of Thanksgiving, but ok. Patient: Yeah. text: Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: But here once we send it they bill your insurance. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Then we get the report back and we’re up to about eight hundred genes that they look at. And some of that actually is important for us because it sometimes can direct what we do whether it’s a trial for now or later and also gets us a sense of what that cancer looks like blueprinted. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Which you know it’s a different blueprint than what you were born with. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm.

text: Patient: Yes, yes. Doctor: So that’s perfect timing then. I’ll see you around the middle to the second half of January and we’ll check your PSA and your testosterone level at that point, about a week or two before. And I’ll give you a paper printout as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And hopefully the PSA will still be quite low at that point so we won’t have to take any action. You guys have any other questions you want to ask while we’re getting this done? Patient: No, No, the Lupron, yeah, yeah. Doctor: Perfect. Glad you’re continuing to do well. Again you look pretty well. Patient: Yeah. I feel great. It’s just the energy. Doctor: Yes. (keyboarding sounds) Patient: Wednesdays are fine. Doctor: That works better for you. Patient: Yes. But I’ll tell you it doesn’t matter. Whatever your schedule dictates. It doesn’t really matter. Doctor: Wednesday should be perfect.

text: Patient: So what kind of pills can I take? Doctor: Huh, so the most common pill would be a drug called abiraterone or enzalutamide. Patient: The enzalutamide, what you were saying- Family Member: Let him, let him, let him ask a colleague a question. He’ll be right back. Patient: I mean I’m just- Doctor: Okay. You remember it? Patient: Well, huh, a doctor from Johns Hopkins two weeks ago worked on a girl, gave her this medicine, and everything disappeared. It’s in the paper. Doctor: But she didn’t have prostate cancer. text: Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For? Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. Yes after the first six to eight weeks. Family Member: But that’s a few months down the road. Patient: And you’d maintain the care?

text: Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?

DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?

DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
